bibl.idno: Papers of Jefferson Randolph Kean [manuscript] / Jefferson Randolph Kean, 1860-1950. MSS 628. The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.

bibl.title: Letter from Thomas M. England to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 2, 1929

div1.p: England compiles a list of medical officers on duty at Camp Columbia and places check marks by the names of individuals he is certain were involved with yellow fever. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Thomas M. England to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 2, 1929
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE ASSISTANT SECRETARY
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Room 2505 Munitions Bldg.
November 2, 1929.
Colonel Jefferson R.Kean,
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I received you note at 4.30 yesterday afternoon and
this morning I have compiled a list of the medical officers on duty at
Camp Columbia, Cuba, I will mark the ones that I remember having to
do with yellow fever“F.Y.”

* I remember Dr. Amador was sanitary inspector and made inspect-
tions of Quemados, Marianao, La Playa, and the surrounding farms for
evidences of yellow fever or the yellow fever mosquitoes. I do not
remember him having anything to do with the patients. As you know
I was not in position to know the duties of all of the above men, so
I have just marked the ones I am certain of.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Thomas M. England Thomas M. England.
Capt., Med. Adm. Corps.
